reviews.review_msg: Mark is unhinged in the best way possible. He's very intense because he's deeply passionate about his subject, but it can make his class a little intimidating, especially at a 100-level. Do the conference if he mentions it, it's definitely worth it. A pretty heavy course, but my final paper for this class is one of my favourites I've ever written.
Interesting lectures but harsh marker.

Mark is a great lecturer and is very passionate about topics covered throughout the course. However, content-wise, this course feels a bit harder than a 100-level course. He is super understanding when it comes to deadlines or late submissions. Attendance is mandatory. Participation is also super important toward your final grade mark.
Mark Deggan was a good prof. He helped students get good understandings of what he wants done. Encourages questions and wants students to do best. Tutorial attendance matters

Great engaging lectures. If you have a slight interest in literature and themes that are commonly brought up in novels, you'll enjoy this class. Dr. Deggan is professional and passionate about the topics he teaches and I would hands down say WL 100 is easily in my top three classes at SFU.

Dr. Deggan is a great lecturer and can make long lectures fly by. He cares a lot about his students and truly wants to see them succeed. He is very approachable and ready to help you whenever you have a question. His courses, however, are reading-heavy and require extra time to prepare for in-class essays and midterms.

Mark is an amazing prof. Imo, the course books were a little difficult to understand but Mark has always been available outside the classroom for help. He is someone who wants to give you a better grade. Moreover, I asked for an extension on one of my assignments due to medical reasons. He not only gave me abundant time but was also very empathetic

The course was chill with Mark but, he is a hard marker. I see him as a passionate prof but he will go on forever on his lectures. His novels were interesting to read but, it was sometime quite difficult to understand those concepts. For a 100 level course this course goes beyond your expectations, this course is NOT a Gpa booster.
Mark is always available outside of tutorial for discussion. He always gives detailed feedback and his teaching style pushes you.

The questions for the papers were extremely complicated for a first year course and his expectations for what was supposed to be written was nearly impossible to do with such little time/word counts. Made tests happen outside of class time when people have other classes and work. Save your time and GPA and do not take it with him.

Did not enjoy this prof or class whatsoever. His exam questions were nearly impossible to understand. I took this class to explore my options and I can officially confirm that world lit is ticked off that list...

Mark is one of the kindest and easiest to talk to Profs I've ever had. He's super passionate about what he's teaching and will give you lots of helpful feedback if you ask for it. He even lets you re-do an in-class essay if you didn't do well on it. His lectures can be a bit confusing but his marking is very fair. Readings are short and simple

Literally one of the best professors at the godforsaken school that is SFU. Beware, he will Not baby you, but it's 100% worth it. You'll come out of his class feeling accomplished and like you actually learned useful stuff. Good grade booster too, especially if you need a breadth course. The only class where I Actually Read Every Text. SHOCKING.

Mark's classes are very lecture heavy, and there's a lot of information thrown at you. I'd recommend just absorbing as much as you can, and if you are confused about anything, ask him about it in office hours. He really focuses on literary theory when analyzing texts, and his reading lists are very diverse and interesting.

You can't go wrong taking one of Mark's classes. Highly entertaining lectures, a good, deep dive into the material. He's open to contesting opinions, and gives great feedback on assignments. This isn't a sleeper class. Go into it wanting to learn for maximum effect.

Had to retake the course again in the Fall. His marking is very harsh and he doesn't seem to have a marking scheme, which makes it hard to do well. It would've been nice if he didn't lecture so fast. Most of the time it was hard to keep up.

Doesn't have empathy towards students. He likes to hear himself talk instead of engaging the class. He believes everyone pays attention through 2h of lecture with no break. You may write the same way, yet your marks will fluctuate. Even if you follow the feedback he gives you, it won't change your mark in future papers. He made the midterm 3h long.

Mark is very fun and interesting as a person, however he is a tough grader and not very clear in what he wants. Unless you are very good at writing I would not recommend him. However, he is very willing to hep and give extra work. He will encourage you to succeed but sometimes that isn't enough.
Will call on random people in class. Ultimately this is a subjective, creative thinking class, but if your opinion is not the prof's opinion then you're wrong lol

extremely nice yall, super flexible, throws jokes here and there, participate in tut's it REALLY helps with boosting your grade (just talk about literary devices from the short stories assigned each week) + gives valuable feedback after essay drafts and more,, is also accessible after class, is very passionate about the course !!

This class was taken online so my review is more reflective of the class than Ken. He reviewed one of my papers when I asked for a grade change though; he was very succinct. The class is a ton of reading; 4 novels, 3 short stories, multiple poems. It's a big time investment and papers are marked harder than usual for an entry level course.
